title: 'My Nectar card was blocked with £370 worth of points on'
text:
A loyal Sainsbury's customer has been left frustrated after Nectar blocked her card with hundreds of pounds on it – without telling her why.

Karen Matthews, 47, first found her loyalty card had been blocked when she received a notification on her Nectar app that stated her points balance was currently unavailable at the beginning of August.

She says she hadn't received an email or letter from Nectar, which is owned by Sainsbury's, suggesting there were any issues so she called it to find out what was going on.

A Nectar customer found her account was blocked when it had £370 worth of points on it

Karen, a merchandiser from Norwich, said: 'The timing was very inconvenient as it fell over my birthday weekend.

'It was frustrating that nobody had thought it appropriate to inform me that my card was under a block because this could have led to my embarrassment at the pump or the till if I had not had another means of payment with me.'

She contacted Nectar who said at first it was not its problem and Karen should instead contact Sainsbury's.

However, after doing so, Sainsbury's said she should speak to Nectar, leaving her in a frustrating position.

She eventually spoke to someone at Sainsbury's who said her Nectar account had been temporarily blocked because it was suspected that there had been fraud on some customers' accounts.

In an email, she was told the card have been unblocked and she was given a thousand points for the inconvenience.

Unfortunately, however, her card remained blocked so she had to start the merry-go-round of telephone calls once more between Nectar and Sainsbury's with both parties stating they were unable to help.

Karen added: 'It should not take such an inordinate amount of time on the telephone and so many telephone calls to try to resolve this issue.'

Mystery: Sainsbury's would not tell Karen why her account had been blocked at first

Eventually Karen was told that her account had been permanently blocked and would not be reopened because the terms and conditions had not been adhered to.

She was given no further information at this time, leaving her unsure what terms were meant to have been broken and whether she could get another Nectar card in the future.

Karen said: 'I was initially grateful that my card was temporarily blocked in order to protect my account from suspected fraud, however, the manner in which this was done and the futile effort I have had to make to try to have the block lifted have been incredibly frustrating.'

She was understandably frustrated as she had £370 worth of points on her card that she had been saving up for Sainsbury's double-up promotion later in the year to buy charity raffle prizes.

Although she hasn't been informed as to the problem, Karen thinks she knows why her card might have been blocked.

Earlier in the year, Nectar were offering bonus points on purchases, for example, 40 points on the purchase of bananas so the purchase of a banana for about 10p would generate 40 points equating to 20p. There was also 100 bonus points on the purchase of a porridge pot costing 50p.

Karen added: 'I don't even like bananas – I was donating them to hostels and the homeless.

'A pot of hot porridge and a banana makes a really good breakfast for someone in need.

'I would quite happily stand at a self-service till with a basket of fifty bananas and pay for them all individually.'

She said the checkout supervisors at Sainsbury's asked her what she was doing when she was buying the bananas and porridge and she told them.

'They were happy to hear about what I was doing, even downloading the app to use themselves and they let me get on with it, even giving me keyboard shortcuts on the till to help me go a bit quicker.'

Whilst Karen believes this is a potential loophole in the system, staff at Sainsbury's never advised it was against any rules and if this was the case, she says she should have been told by the team, rather than just having her card blocked.

Since This is Money contacted Nectar regarding the issue, Karen's card has been unblocked with all £370 of her points still available as well as an extra thousand points as initially promised to her by a member of the Nectar team.

A Nectar spokesperson said: 'We have apologised to Karen for the delay and reactivated her card.'

Since receiving the news, Karen has said that she is going to try and cash out the funds as soon as possible, just in case something like this happens again.

This isn't the first time This is Money has reported on customers having issues with their Nectar card.

A number of Nectar users complained last year about having points go missing from their Nectar account with no explanation.
